title: Part 2: Helping Kids Handle Big Emotions – Tools for Empathy, Calming Down, and Resilience
content:
Introduction

Once your child can recognize and talk about their feelings, the next step is helping them respond in healthy ways. In Part 2 of our Emotional Intelligence series, we’ll share real-life tools for teaching empathy, calming strategies, and how to build emotional resilience.

Tip 4: Model Empathy and Kindness

Your child learns empathy by watching you. Narrate kind actions you take: “I’m going to help Grandma because she’s not feeling well.”

Also reflect empathy back to your child: “You’re feeling scared. That’s okay. I’m here with you.”

Praise kind behavior when you see it: “That was so thoughtful when you shared your toy.”

Tip 5: Teach Calming Strategies for Big Emotions

Show your child how to:

  • Take deep breaths (“Smell the flower, blow out the candle”)
  • Use a calm-down corner
  • Cuddle a favorite stuffed animal
  • Draw or move their body when overwhelmed

Practice these tools when they’re calm so they remember them when upset.

Tip 6: Encourage Problem-Solving and Resilience

When something goes wrong, guide your child:

  • “What could you try instead?”
  • “Let’s figure it out together.”

Celebrate when they try again: “You didn’t give up, even when it was hard. That’s brave!”

Wrap-Up

Big feelings are part of growing up. With your help, your child can learn to handle them with grace, confidence, and kindness. Keep building their emotional toolbox — one moment at a time.
